When developers came around 2 years ago with plans to replace the dilapidated homes of Liberty Square, Sharon Gregory didn’t believe them.  Now, Gregory is the proud resident of a brand new apartment after Miami-Dade County, along with Related Urban Development Group, launched the first phase of a plan to redevelop Liberty Square in Miami on Monday, July 1, 2019. HUD Secretary Dr. Ben Carson also was on hand to unveil the new apartments. When the final three phases are completed by 2023, the $300 million Liberty Square development will house 1,455 units of all price ranges, from public housing to market rate. Welcome to 2020, Miami. For this week, at least, the city is at the epicenter of presidential primary politics. Here's a view of the debate stage at the Adrienne Arsht Center for the Performing Arts, where 20 Democratic candidates will spar on Wednesday and Thursday, June 26-27, 2019, in their quest to win the party's nomination. Photos by @pportalphoto and @aldiazphoto  #democraticparty #democrat #2020presidentialrace #campaign2020 #miami #politics

Ahead of the first Democratic primary debates at the Adrienne Arsht Center in downtown Miami, there was a political buzz in the air on Tuesday, June 25, 2019, as candidates courted voters throughout Miami-Dade. Former U.S. Rep. Beto O'Rourke shared his platform in North Miami at a town hall with the American Federation of Teachers, and U.S. Sen. Elizabeth Warren held a town hall at FIU. But not to be outdone, Republican leaders are also in town holding counter-events. Vice President Mike Pence was at the DoubleTree by Hilton Miami Airport Hotel to help launch "Latinos for Trump," a coalition devoted to mobilizing Hispanic support for President Donald Trump's reelection campaign. Photos by Jennifer King, Pedro Portal, Daniel A. Varela and Jose A. Iglesias. #2020election #democrat #democraticprimary #republican #campaign2020 #miami

Stephen's Deli has been on the same corner in Hialeah since 1954. In that time, the family of Scott Nadelman, left, has owned it longer than any other owner. For two years, Jean "BJ" Lucel and Wesley Bissaint would haul their smoker and grill around Miami's Little Haiti neighborhood to cook roadside barbecue. Their dining rooms were weed-covered lots, the parking lot outside Lucel's tattoo shop and weekend popups at the Little Haiti Cultural Complex. But as outsiders set their eyes on Little Haiti real estate, Lucel and Bissaint staked their claim with Bon Gout Barbecue at 99 NW 54th St., serving up American Southern barbecue with a Haitian twist.  Miselie “Mamma Chef” Marseilles, Bissaint's mother, handles the handful of traditional Haitian dishes at the restaurant. Now their dining room fills up with regulars. Photos by @jiglesias56. #littlehaiti #miami #barbecue 
To read the story, click the link in our bio.

Customers at several South Florida Vicky Bakery stores recently noticed something different. The menu was larger, with different flavors of pastelitos and other treats and new sandwiches. Oh, and one more thing: It wasn’t a Vicky’s anymore. 
This is @caobakery, owned by Tony Cao, the grandson of @vickybakery founder Antonio Cao. He bought out his seven Vicky stores, split off and started his own bakeries, carrying the family name. “We wanted a next generation bakery,” Tony Cao said. The new menu fuses Cuban cuisine with American traditions.

After a four-year, $15 million makeover, the Estefans are ready to unveil the renovations to this historic Miami Beach hotel. “The whole thing is new,” said @emilioestefanjr, who owns the hotel with @gloriaestefan. "Bathrooms, floors, air conditioners. That’s why it took us four years. I said if we’re going to do it, let’s do it first class." But when the celebrity couple bought the Cardozo Hotel in 1992, many questioned the investment. "People said, 'Why are you buying on Ocean Drive? It’s all old people,'" Emilio Estefan said. "Everything changed and you have to go with the changes. Ocean Drive represents Miami, it’s a perfect example of what Miami is all about." This is the last house standing in what was once a pleasant residential neighborhood in Coral Gables. All other homes on the block were bulldozed to make way for the largest commercial development in Coral Gables’ history that will encompass 1.1 million square feet of condos, offices, shops, restaurants, parking garages and a hotel. But these owners are staying put.  Lucia Capote and her son Orlando refuse to sell to developers, real estate agents or flippers for their house. “This is home. Beneath highway overpasses, hard by a county jail, inside barbed-wire fencing and perched above a concrete-colored pond, it's a sight for sore eyes: Egrets. A couple hundred egrets have found a winter home in Overtown,  just north of Northwest 14th Street between Northwest Seventh Avenue and I-95  next to the Miami-Dade Women's Detention Center. "Give it a bit of a chance and it's remarkable what will happen despite the fact that we've done our best to destroy their habitat." Read the full story at MiamiHerald.com.

The view from Luz Pabon’s fourth-floor condo in Little Havana isn’t what it used to be. When she bought her unit in 2002, she could watch the July 4th fireworks at Bayfront Park from her balcony. Today, they're blocked by the towers that have sprouted up and down the Brickell corridor over the last 15 years.

Now she and her fellow condo residents want out. "It’s too commercial. What has happened here is a catastrophe. This is no longer for us. Two teenage boys in Haiti have advanced forms of cancer. One boy, 14-year-old Djonsly, is being treated in Miami after finding help through a charity. The other, 17-year-old Djooly, is struggling to get treatment in Haiti's broken healthcare system. 
Haiti only has 10 pediatric hospital beds devoted to cancer, and only one MRI machine in the whole country. Cancer is a taboo subject in Haiti, and some parents are told by doctors simply that "children don't get cancer." Today in our series #CancerinHaiti we look at some of the most vulnerable cancer patients in the country: children. Full story at hrld.us/childrenscancerinhaiti. Link in bio. #cancer #pediatriccancer #childhoodcancer #haiti

Cervical cancer is preventable and treatable. It’s also one of the leading causes of cancer deaths for women in Haiti. But it doesn’t have to be that way. “It is a preventable epidemic,” said one doctor who has researched the issue for 25 years. “Honestly, nobody should die of this disease.” And yet, cervical cancer is treated as a death sentence. 
That’s because in the entire country of 11 million people, there is only one MRI scanner and no radiation machines. There are just three places in Haiti where middle-class and poor people have any hope of getting care they can afford. And the HPV vaccine, recommended for children as young as 11 to prevent cervical cancer, is still not widely available.

Today we launch our #CancerinHaiti series, exploring a public health crisis that Haiti cannot afford. Read more at MiamiHerald.com/cancerinhaiti. Link in bio. #cervicalcancer #cancer #haiti #womenshealth

Despite spending as much as $3.2 billion, the federal effort over the past year to restore power to Puerto Rico didn’t build a better and more resilient system. In fact, the grid is more fragile. A severe new storm would put the island's 3.3 million residents into deep trouble.

Weary of constant blackouts, more Puerto Ricans are now turning to solar energy, as seen on this home, one of 28 households participating in a solar energy project in the Toro Negro community in the mountains of Ciales. Full report at hrld.us/forgottenisland-solar.

Photo by @aldiazphoto #ForgottenIsland #PuertoRico #solarpower #solarenergy #solar #hurricanemaria #borinquen

Hundreds of Puerto Rican schools closed after Hurricane Maria, and special needs students were particularly affected. Even a year after the storm, parents were left struggling to find classrooms, teachers and therapists for their children with autism, Down syndrome or cerebral palsy. 
Pictured, Brenda Lopez kisses her 7-year-old son Angel Miguel Torres, who has cerebral palsy. When she brought Angel to school at the beginning of the school year, she found a cramped space where the air conditioning barely worked, the bathroom was too small for his wheelchair, and there was no diaper changing table. There was also no teacher. 
Read our full report at https://hrld.us/forgottenisland-specialneeds.

Photo by Pedro Portal #ForgottenIsland #PuertoRico #specialneeds #hurricanemaria #autism #cerebralpalsy #downsyndrome #borinquen

After Hurricane Maria left his local hospital infested with toxic mold, 65-year-old  Radamés Cabral  travels 10 to 12 hours for kidney dialysis. He does this three times a week. "I have no life anymore. My quality of life is zero.” While the government says all 68 of Puerto Rico's public and private hospitals are up and running, that statistic doesn’t paint the full picture.  Full story at hrld.us/forgottenisland-healthcare

Photo by @aldiazphoto #PuertoRico #ForgottenIsland #HurricaneMaria #Borinquen

A year after Hurricane Maria, about 60,000 occupied homes in Puerto Rico still don't have roofs. Here, the Caño Martin Peña area of San Juan is pictured in August. About 332,000 Puerto Rican householders have had their applications for FEMA aid denied. The overriding reason: Recipients must prove they own and occupy the damaged dwellings -- even though the island's legal code does not require most homeowners to have a deed.

That means many legitimate homeowners have no way to satisfy FEMA’s requirements even when property has been in the family for generations, experts say. Full story at hrld.us/forgottenisland-housing.

Photo by @matiasocner #puertorico #forgottenisland #hurricanemaria #borinquen

This is a tale of what lies in a too-often forgotten place down a too-often forgotten street in a too-often forgotten neighborhood: The story of Miami’s historic black cemeteries.
.
http://hrld.us/caretakers
.
#miami #blackhistory #miamihistory #cemetery #graveyard

Lincoln Memorial Park Cemetery, like at least two other surviving black burial grounds in Miami-Dade, exemplifies a significant though little-known legacy of racial segregation. Before the Civil Rights Act of 1964 ended legal segregation in America, black and white people were separated not just in life, but in death, too.
.

See more photos from this essay and read more about this history of Miami’s black cemeteries at http://hrld.us/caretakers. (Link in bio)
.
#miami #cemetery #miamihistory #blackhistory #graveyard

This is the final resting place for an estimated 10,000 to 30,000 African Americans, lynching victims and millionaires alike, pressed together in the equality of their legal inequality.
.
http://hrld.us/caretakers
.
#miamihistory #blackhistory #cemetery #graveyard #miami

Buried at Lincoln Memorial are Miami’s first black millionaire, the first female black Florida legislator, the founder of The Miami Times, and one of Miami’s first black physicians. So are dozens of veterans of wars spanning a century, from the Civil War through Vietnam. 
http://hrld.us/caretakers
.
#miamihistory #blackhistory #cemetery #graveyard #miami

“I’m a third generation Miamian and I had never heard of this cemetery before.”
.
It’s unclear how many black cemeteries existed in Miami-Dade. At least three have been obliterated. And some just appear to have been forgotten.
.
http://hrld.us/caretakers
.
#cemetery #graveyard #blackhistory #miamihistory #miami

Today, the historic legacy of black cemeteries across the South is in trouble. With no fencing and no security, Miami’s Lincoln Memorial Park Cemetery is littered with refuse, Santería offerings and discarded drug paraphernalia. Vaults are sometimes broken open by grave robbers and the skeletal remains inside taken for use in religious rituals or to be sold on the black market.
.
But there’s hope. The @coralgablesmuseum has taken on the cause of Lincoln Memorial. Its staff has organized cleanups and restorations. An exhibition on the cemetery opens Aug. 3. 
See more of @cjmiamiherald’s photos from the exhibit and a mini-documentary at http://hrld.us/caretakers. Link in bio.
.
#cemetery #blackhistory #miamihistory #graveyard #miami

Has Lincoln Road lost its charm? The famous Miami Beach outdoor mall keeps growing — yet its small businesses keep closing, replaced by global brands with the means to rent large spaces and draw tourists. "There are too many corporate stores on Lincoln Road," said the part-owner of The Shoe Shop, which is going out of business. "There's a price war, and we're not Amazon. We can't compete... Lincoln Road is just like Aventura Mall now. They don't make small businesses want to stay." Read more at MiamiHerald.com/business.

"He is the first chef in the history of the world to be sued by a sitting president. He is my hero," said Anthony Bourdain of activist and fellow chef José Andrés at a dinner during the 2017 South Beach Wine & Food Festival.

Bourdain, who died this week at age 61, admired Andrés' stand against President Donald Trump after canceling plans to open a restaurant at the Trump Hotel in D.C. over the president's comments about immigrants.

But he also admired Miami and frequently highlighted the city in his TV shows "24-Hour Layover," "Parts Unknown" and "No Reservations." Read more at MiamiHerald.com

Just a day after graduation, the Parkland shooting survivors announced they're taking their activism on tour this summer to register young voters and promote gun law changes. On Monday, about two dozen students announced the #MarchforOurLives: Road to Change tour, which will stop in every Florida congressional district, plus 20 states. Prominent March for Our Lives organizers including @davidmileshogg, #EmmaGonzalez, @cameronkasky and @jackiecorin were on hand for the announcement. Congratulations to the Marjory Stoneman Douglas class of 2018! During a large but private graduation ceremony Sunday, #MSD seniors donned their caps and gowns to collect their diplomas and close the door on a school year marked by tragedy. Four graduating seniors who were killed in February's school shooting were honored with posthumous diplomas and a glass-encased cap, and a moment of silence was held for the 17 victims of the shooting. Comedian Jimmy Fallon surprised the students as their commencement speaker. "You are not just the future - you are the present. Keep changing the world. Keep making us proud," @jimmyfallon later tweeted. Read our full story at MiamiHerald.com. #MSDStrong #ParklandStrong #Parkland #NeverAgain #Enough #classof2018

Few would consider Greater Downtown Miami as a place for parents to raise their kids, but a new analysis of census data proves otherwise. Since 2010, the number of family households living in the area jumped 42 percent, including a 53 percent spike in children aged 14 and under. "When we first moved here, we felt like pioneers, because Brickell was definitely not family-oriented," said one 39-year-old resident. "Back then, this was primarily a financial business district. But all that has changed drastically." This means people like Angie Salazar, a Brickell resident pictured here with her grandson, can expect things more schools and accessible walkways. Full story at MiamiHerald.com. Photo by Sam Navarro #downtownmiami #miami #brickell

Remember this? 35 years ago, a Bulgarian artist known as Christo and his French wife Jeanne-Claude dressed up 11 islands in Biscayne Bay in floating hot-pink skirts. @christojeanneclaude  asked for no money, pledging to personally bear the full cost. The elaborate installation would be in place for two weeks, then removed without a trace. Miami's response, when not downright hostile, amounted to a collective, dumbfounded "Huh?" When it was all over, our city was forever changed.

More photos, plus a look back at the "Surrounded Islands" project is at MiamiHerald.com. Archival photo via @AP #BiscayneBay #Miami #SurroundedIslands #Miamihistory #arthistory

Legendary Miami Hurricanes baseball coach Jim Morris coached his final home game Saturday of an illustrious 41-year career— the past 25 leading the Hurricanes to 13 College World Series berths and national championships in 1999 and 2001.  His family and about 35 former players, all his current players, 50-year public address announcer Jay Rokeach and athletic director Blake James took part in a touching pregame ceremony. Morris' 6-year-old son Will threw out the first pitch. "That was my only request,'' Morris said, "that my son throw out the first pitch, and that I catch it." Photos by Sam Navarro #um #umbaseball #miamihurricanes #hurricanesbaseball #itsallabouttheu

Little Havana will soon be home to Miami's first chocolate factory! In a small factory, Exquisito Fine Choclates owner Carolina Quijano is hoping to whet Miami’s appetite for chocolate made only in the 305 -- and you may have already tasted her sweets without knowing it. Miami favorites @azucaricecream and @thesaltydonut both use her stuff. "The second I tasted it, I melted," said Azúcar's owner. "I'm thrilled with it. The public is thrilled with it. You can taste the difference." The @exquisitochocolates factory, on Southwest Eighth Street and 27th Avenue, opens Saturday. 
Full story at MiamiHerald.com/restaurants

#chocolate #littlehavana #chocolatemaker #miami

Author Tom Wolfe visits the Miami Herald newsroom in 2009. Wolfe died Monday in New York City at age 88. In a 2012 interview with the Herald, the 'New Journalism' writer talked about Miami's immigrant community and how much Hialeah has changed. “It dawned on me one day that Miami is the only city in the world where people from another country, with another language and another culture, have taken over at the voting booth. They don’t meld the way immigrants have in other cities. ” He also showed a fondness for a Miami fashion staple. "The guayabera is the answer, no bothering with a tie or jacket. So I’m busy trying to come up with an American guayabera.” Our full interview is at MiamiHerald.com/people. #tomwolfe

A split-second decision saved Kyle Laman's life in the #Parkland shooting. But the trauma now haunts the 15-year-old freshman. Kyle, who was shot in the ankle, was in the hospital for 16 days and bedridden for more than a month. For the the past 2 1/2 months, he has begun to bear new burdens: the crippling guilt of survival, the excruciating process of recovery, the tormenting reminders of that day.  We spent the last month with Kyle and his family (and the German Shepherd service dog he's training to help with his anxiety) to talk about his story of survival. Full article at MiamiHerald.com.
#msdstrong #msd #parklandstrong #neveragain

What a mess: West Flagler Street in Little Havana has been under construction for nearly 2 1/2 years, and what began as an improvement project looks more like a destruction project. All along the once-bustling artery lined with restaurants and shops that are the lifeblood of Miami’s immigrant economy, small businesses are dying. "We are barely surviving. This project has done more harm than good," said one restaurant owner. Full story at MiamiHerald.com/little-havana. #littlehavana #miami

H. Wayne Huizenga, billionaire entrepreneur and South Florida sports icon, has died at age 80 in Fort Lauderdale.  Huizenga was the only entrepreneur ever to launch three Fortune 500 companies: Waste Management, Blockbuster Entertainment and AutoNation.  He's considered the father of both hockey and baseball in South Florida as the original owner of the Florida Marlins and Florida Panthers, which both began play in 1993. Read more about Huizenga's life and his influence on our community at MiamiHerald.com. #floridapanthers #marlins #dolphins #miamidolphins #flapanthers

The Tower Hotel in Little Havana has lived many lives. The historic building bore witness to the transformation of Southwest Eighth Street into Calle Ocho. “It’s seen the blues. It’s seen the whole American people down there. It was a Jewish community. And then it was Cuban through El Mariel,” said David Schechtman, whose family owned the Tower Hotel from 1955 to 2012. "Through all the different cultural and history changes.” Now, the hotel is due for another major change, as Little Havana's first boutique hotel. Full story at MiamiHerald.com. Photo by Pedro Portal/@elnuevoherald staff #littlehavana #miami #towerhotel #calleocho #miamihistory

The gold molded into our wedding rings, dangling around our necks and even hidden in our smart phones pollutes the rainforest with toxic chemicals and exploits workers in Latin America. The Macy's in downtown Miami, once the site of Burdines' flagship store, is closing. The downtown location is one of 11 Macy's stores around the nation getting the axe. When the temperature drops in Miami, the line for churros and hot chocolate at La Palma can get long. Really long. On Wednesday evening, the line grew to more than 100 people waiting for their cold weather treat. “This is our annual tradition when it gets a little frío, since it’s so rare that it gets cold in Miami,” said one woman in line. Read more at Miami.com. #churros #hotchocolate #lapalma #miami #winterinmiami via @miami_com

That giant 93-foot glass-and-steel slide that’s been tantalizing shoppers at Aventura Mall for months is finally ready to ride. The “Aventura Slide Tower,” which was designed by German sculptor Carsten Höller, is the crowning touch in the first phase of Aventura Mall’s ambitious, $214 million expansion. Additions include a luxurious food hall, a covered parking garage, art installations and several new, world-famous tenants.

These are the first new Metrorail cars, billed as the answer to many of the system's problems. The cars are newer, so they shouldn't be subject to breakdowns as often and are easier to repair. Other upgrades include: built-in bike racks, a breezier layout, new air-conditioning equipment and security cameras. Pictured, Director of Miami-Dade Transportation Alice Bravo stands inside one of the new cars. Read more about the upgrades at MiamiHerald.com. #metrorail #miami

A group of Key West women gather to assemble meals at the home of Margit Bisztray. Miami, with its beach weather and fondness for retro, has a new car to love. The iconic ’60s Moke has relaunched with the slogan, “Always on vacation.” The open-air beach buggy — typically in bold colors like orange and yellow — began limited distribution in May to the United States out of Miami-based @mokeusa. The car was made famous in the ’60s and ’70s as a favorite among celebrities and the social elite, and once counted the Beach Boys, Frank Sinatra, George Harrison and even James Bond among its fans. Meet Arctic, a Siberian husky who was just sworn in as the newest member of the El Portal Police Department. Arctic is the first community K-9 for the police squad and his role is therapeutic, said El Portal police officer Ronnie Hufnagel. “Arctic is not a bite, drug, bomb or sniff dog,” she said. "He can somehow make all of your problems, complaints and even your sorrow go away if even for a little while." Photos by Roberto Koltun / el Nuevo Herald.

These PVC pipes are used to create coral nurseries, part of a restoration effort led by the University of Miami. The "Rescue a Reef" project originally started as a citizen science project and grew into a massive rescue effort to rebuild the nation's only inshore reef. Miami Seaquarium visitors can now view a miniature coral garden up close at an exhibit that features the same coral "trees" used in nurseries. Pictured here: Seaquarium summer campers Maddie Volpe, 10, and Madison Lord, 11, check out the exhibit last week. Full story at MiamiHerald.com/environment. Photo by Jose A. Flagler Cottage, the historic 1897 house built by Henry Flagler for his workers, has been vacant, neglected and fenced off for years. All that could change as the Dade Heritage Trust wants to turn the house into a visitors' center to serve as a historical tribute to Flagler, known as the "Father of Miami." The proposal also calls for new landscaping, and opening a small cafe and a bike-rental shop so people can ride on the underutilized Miami River greenway. Full story at MiamiHerald.com. #henryflagler #flagler #miami #history

Fontainebleau hotel housekeeper Odelie Paret climbs out of bed at 4:30 a.m., as she does each weekday, to start her commute from Opa-locka to Miami Beach. More than 80 percent of the workers employed in Miami Beach don't live there. That means every morning, workers like Paret commute for hours to get to the Beach, where stagnant wages and high rents have pushed them farther and farther away. Damaris Hall is graduating with a master's degree in national security from Nova Southeastern University. Her son James Hall is also a student at NSU, working toward a master's in international business. You can sometimes catch them at Starbucks working on their papers and research projects. “I think we are alike. We take education very seriously,” James said. Both are looking forward to her graduation after Mother's Day. Read her story, and the stories of other moms who went back to school, at MiamiHerald.com/living. #nova #nsu #nsusuccess #mothersday #novasoutheasternuniversity

Gloria Jimenez is putting five of her seven daughters through college while attending Miami Dade College herself. And she actually beat them to graduation, earning her degree two weeks ago. Miami's suburbs hold the last few remnants of the world's rarest forest: the pine rockland.  It once covered 186,000 acres. Today it's down to about 3,700 outside Everglades National Park. So little is left that many of its inhabitants — bats, snakes, butterflies, beetles and a host of plants — are in danger of disappearing too. Get an up-close look at the pine rockland, and read about a developer's plans for a Walmart shopping center on some of that land at MiamiHerald.com/environment. Photos by Patrick Farrell/Miami Herald Staff

The day Enrique Sepulveda filled out his application to Miami Dade College, he had to think hard about what to write down for his home address. That's because at 19 years old, Sepulveda was homeless. On Saturday, the now-22-year-old graduated from MDC with an Associate of Arts degree. “I’ve had to overcome a lot of obstacles,” said the Miami native, who was also elected vice president of the student body. “But people need to know that my story is not unique, that there are many people in my same situation.” Read his story at MiamiHerald.com/education. Photo by Pedro Portal/el Nuevo Herald Staff #miamidadecollege #mdc #miami #graduation #mdcgrad

In the 1960s, Craig Curry became the first black quarterback at Coral Gables Senior High, after his high school was closed due to court-ordered integration. Curry led his team to state and national championships, helping forge the integration of Gables High through the unifying force of football. "Craig was our Jackie Robinson," said his teammate Bertram Taylor, the school's first black running back. Read his story at MiamiHerald.com. #blackhistorymonth #coralgables #miami #history

A pair of singing snake catchers from India are helping solve the riddle for finding Burmese pythons in the Everglades. Since arriving in early January, Masi Sadaiyan, pictured, and Vadivel Gopal, both members of the Irula tribe, India’s famed snake hunters, have headed into the Everglades almost daily in search of the invasive species. They're working with a team of UF biologists and a South Florida herpetologist to teach them new techniques for catching the elusive pythons. Full story at MiamiHerald.com/environment. No, you’re not hallucinating. That really was a giant rainbow. At night.

Monday, Yvette Mattern’s massive lightshow, “Global Rainbow,” debuted for a six-night show. The laser-light installation is broadcast from the top of the Design District offices of Lionheart Capital, developer of The Ritz-Carlton Residences in Miami Beach, which commissioned the work for Miami Art Week. Made of seven color light beams, the light installation is scheduled to be broadcast nightly through Saturday from 6:30 to midnight.

Pamela Cooreman, upper right, from Minnesota, smiles as she savors a dip in the ocean off Miami Beach's North Beach on Saturday, June 4, 2016, with volunteers from the Sabrina Cohen Foundation. Cooreman is in Miami for several months to take part in a clinical trial led by The Miami Project to Cure Paralysis. The nonprofit Sabrina Cohen Foundation works to fund and develop fitness and recreational programs to better the quality of life for people living with disabilities. Its Adaptive Beach Days program includes putting down wheelchair-accessible paths on the sand to allow for access to the ocean and aqua therapy, beach wheelchairs and an adaptive surfboard, art therapy, chair yoga and meditation, and a team of volunteers to assist participants. The summer program schedule is from 10 a.m. to 2 p.m. the first and third Saturdays of the month on the beach at 6475 Collins Ave. Photo by @MarshaHalper / #MiamiHerald #ElNuevoHerald 
#SabrinaCohenFoundation #MiamiProjectToCureParalysis #MiamiBeach

Ninety years ago this September, the unthinkable happened: a raging, Category 4 hurricane plowed across Miami Beach and slammed downtown Miami, leaving a trail of misery and destruction that hurricane experts say remains one of the costliest storms in U.S. history. Many of Miami’s streets were flooded after a 12-foot storm surge swept across Biscayne Boulevard as shown in this #MiamiHerald file photo. As the 2016 hurricane season kicks off on Wednesday, get tips for staying safe and read more about the 1926 hurricane at MiamiHerald.com

Cat advocates say trapping is futile and that proper management works best. Father and son carpenters, Carlos Coello Sr., and Carlos Coello Jr., give Maria Posada 65, a lift back to her Miami Beach condo Friday, Oct. 9, 2015. She headed out to a doctor's appointment, but decided the water was too high. The Coellos were building a deck nearby. 
The high tide came in about a foot higher than predicted Friday, according to preliminary measurements by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Association. Like on Thursday, the unusually high sea levels caused saltwater to seep through storm drains and over the seawall along Indian Creek Drive. 
The National Weather Service has issued a coastal flooding advisory for South Florida through 2 p.m. Sunday.

From left, in front: Miami-Dade County School Board Member Dorothy Bendross-Mindingall; former State Representative Carrie Meek (District 17); Miami-Dade County Schools Superintendent Alberto Carvalho; and Miami-Dade County School Board Member Wilbert "Tee" Holloway cut the ribbon to the Georgia Jones-Ayers Legacy Room in the newly-named Georgia Jones-Ayers Middle School in Miami. At back center is Principal Bernard Edwards. A renaming and dedication ceremony for the school, formerly Allapattah Middle School, was Saturday, Aug. 29, 2015. The Miami-Dade School Board on June 17, 2015, unanimously voted to rename the school after Jones-Ayers, a civil rights leader and community activist who died in February at age 86. Jones-Ayers grew up in the Railroad Shop Colored Addition neighborhood, now Allapattah, originally built for black railroad employees. In 1947, families were evicted from their homes in order to erect a school and park to serve the surrounding white families. Among her accomplishments, Jones-Ayers founded the Alternative Program, a pre-trial intervention program that also assists with post-release job placement. The school is at 1331 NW 46th St. Photo by Marsha Halper / Miami Herald staff

An officer attends the services held by the Miami Gardens Police Department Wednesday for a K-9 officer killed in the line of duty. Max, a German Shepherd, died after being mortally injured investigating a burglary call in the city on Sept. 12. Officials said Max was sent into the home through a window, but a glass panel fell on him and severely cut his ear. Max was taken to Hollywood Animal Hospital for surgery, but during the procedure, veterinarians said his cardiovascular system failed and they were unable to save him. Photo by Walter Michot / Miami Herald #miami #k9 #dog
